title: Improved Phase Discrimination in Power Plant Steels using In-Column Secondary Electron Detectors and Spherical Indexing
content: Tempered martensite ferritic (TMF) steels with 9â€“12%Cr are used extensively for high-temperature steam pipes, turbines, and boilers in electrical power plants. The steels are stable during creep exposure due to the pinning forces exerted by particles of different origin. During in-service creep conditions, these nanometer sized precipitates evolve, which decreases the pinning forces exerted by the particles leading to a decrease in the long-range internal stress field [1]. Quantitative measurements of these secondary phases can potentially be used for remnant-life predictions of service exposed components and to study the microstructural stability of newly developed material grades.
